concept.title: Cheque protocol
concept.shortdesc: Cheque protocol solves a common multi-sig use-cases

conbody.p: A cheque is an off-chain message issued to an identifier about some digital rights.
For example, a cryptographic version of the following messae would be a cheque:person identified by bob@example.com can redeem 1 amount of XToken, signed by Alice
In TokenScript, a cheque is modeled with a TokenScript and deliverred with a customised X.509 message. Such a cheque can be used with a smart contract to redeem the said digital right.

To use cheque on the blockchain it's necessary to cryptographically hide the identifier so that even an adversary who knows the identifier could not link a blockchain transaction to the identifier. Cheque protocol achieves this through Pedersen Commitment and Zero Knowledge Proof.
There are lots of real life use-cases of Cheque Protocol

ul.li: Sending crypto asset without knowing the recipent's public key / Ethereum address.

note.p: We take an product-first, paper-later appraoch. A paper will be published based on the protocol for send token by identifier attestation MVP.

section.title: Cheque protocol adds privacy protection
section.p: Furthermore, proper cryptographic hiding is needed to protect privacy involving protocols that ues attestations.

section.title: Cheque protocol can improve security
section.p: Smart use of Cheque protocol can improve security through minimising counter-party risk and attack surface.

For example, an exchange can get an order from a user to sell their cryptocurrency at certain price. Later when the order can be filled, the exchange can counter-sign the order and execute it. This can happen even when the user is offline.

Therefore the user does not need to deposite their cryptocurrency into the exchange's account prior to the trade, minimising counter party risk. The exchange account will be holding cryptocurrency only for a short time, minimising attack surface.
